author: sky.cactus
content: <@!689161464829050960> What do you mean by "adding bytecode prefixes"?

author: samwilsn
content:
<@!301186049323958275> The EIP specifies that clients only propagate AA transactions if the targetted contract begins with a standard bytecode prefix. Down the road, we'd like to expand to allow multiple standard bytecode prefixes (if the `IS_STATIC` EIP gets accepted, for example.)

Since the list of allowed prefixes only affects pending transactions, adding a new prefix wouldn't be a consensus critical change, but I think it would still warrant a new EIP?

author: sky.cactus
content: <@!689161464829050960> I recommend splitting up the transaction propogation rules and the consensus rules into different EIPs.

author: sky.cactus
content: Things tend to go smoother when you have smaller EIPs, and while one may depend on the other, the two are not inexorably tied together.

author: sky.cactus
content: ü§î Actually, propogation rules aren't EIP worthy in general... so maybe not.

author: hudsonjameson
content:
<@!301186049323958275> <@!425279588009246720> <@!187490121698770945> We have an EIPIP meeting in about 11 hours if you all can make it. We will probably be discussing the Abandoned vs Withdrawn thing again.
https://github.com/ethereum-cat-herders/EIPIP/issues/33

author: sky.cactus
content: Has EIP-1 been updated with the new statuses yet?

author: hudsonjameson
content: I don't believe so. Are you talking about this PR? https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/issues/2941

author: sky.cactus
content: No.  We agreed on a previous call to update EIP-1 with the proposed statuses.

author: sky.cactus
content: I still standby that we should do that *first*, and then discuss maybe iterating after that on withdrawn/abanddoned.

author: sky.cactus
content: I dislike holding up making *any* changes until we hash out this detail.

author: sky.cactus
content: Essentially, we have agreed to change to the following, and I think we should implement that and then Axic or Pooja can make a PR that proposes changing from there.

author: sky.cactus
content: I'm a big fan of an iterative process, and we have agreement on an iteration that I think we all agree is strictly better than the current situation.

author: hudsonjameson
content:
> I dislike holding up making any changes until we hash out this detail.

I think that detail would hold up people from making changes to existing draft EIPs or current, recent PRs as well. Or worse, they would have to change their header stuff twice if we revert or modify the decision to include extra header data.

author: sky.cactus
content: I will volunteer to do a mass change of Stagnant to Withdrawn if we end up going with Axic's suggestion so authors don't have to deal with it.

author: sky.cactus
content: There is not any loss of information between the two, so they are convertible between each other without author interaction I believe.

author: hudsonjameson
content: Okay. I am thinking others would volunteer to help you do the bulk changes too. I'm comfortable iterating.

author: hudsonjameson
content:
However, I don't think those changes are in EIP-1 yet.

*goes to check*

author: hudsonjameson
content: `Withdrawn` is not in there.

author: hudsonjameson
content: Also, <@!425279588009246720>'s EIP overhaul  document doesn't seem to be up to speed with opinions from the EIPIP meeting (not to say he has to be aware or even agree with whatever decisions come from the meeting, but it would be nice to all get on the same page). https://hackmd.io/@axic/eip-overhaul

author: madeof_tin7509
content: Yes, we should add Axics proposal to have a reason field for withdrawn.

author: sky.cactus
content: So in response to your original comment, I'm totally up for discussing Abandoned/Withdrawn in todays meeting.  I just *also* think we should move forward with updating EIP-1 to match previous consensus while we hash that out (one does not need to block the other).

author: madeof_tin7509
content: And then we can make a proposal to deprecate Stangant after we have a chance to get something out the door.

author: madeof_tin7509
content: And roll it into the reason field at that time.

author: hudsonjameson
content: I'm good with that. Let's confirm on the meeting tomorrow, but whoever wants to can write the PR. I don't have time tonight unfortunately :/ If it isn't written tonight we will see who can do it in tomorrow's meeting.

author: sky.cactus
content: I'm already way behind, and will likely fall even more behind (and possibly be completely unavailable) over the next 2-4 weeks.  üò¢

author: hudsonjameson
content: Oh no! Sorry, that's no fun when that happens <@!301186049323958275>. Totes understand.

author: sky.cactus
content: I should be able to make the call tonight at least.

author: samwilsn
content:
<@!301186049323958275> 

> I recommend splitting up the transaction propogation rules and the consensus rules into different EIPs. Things tend to go smoother when you have smaller EIPs, and while one may depend on the other, the two are not inexorably tied together.

I think we could split it up into a couple EIPs, but we'd lose the overarching story and it'd be harder to follow. Is that an issue?

> ü§î Actually, propogation rules aren't EIP worthy in general... so maybe not.

How would you publish and standardize the prefixes without an EIP? I know EIP-1 is getting reworked, but it does mention `changes that are not necessarily consensus critical but may be relevant to ‚Äúcore dev‚Äù discussions`.

author: sky.cactus
content:
> I think we could split it up into a couple EIPs, but we'd lose the overarching story and it'd be harder to follow. Is that an issue?
EIPs are technical specifications, not stories.  üôÇ

author: sky.cactus
content: I recommend blogs, YouTube, Reddit, GitHub repository, etc. for stories, best practices, good ideas, etc.

author: sky.cactus
content: EIPs are for specifications.  By the time someone is looking at the EIP they *probably* already have a plan to implement it and they are just looking for the technical details.

author: sky.cactus
content:
> changes that are not necessarily consensus critical but may be relevant to ‚Äúcore dev‚Äù discussions
<@!689161464829050960> I'm *personally* a bit of a downer on Informational EIPs.  I would personally rather see the EIPs repository be purely technical specifications with strict bounds on what is acceptable.  However, not everyone agrees and the rules currently do allow for informational EIPs so I won't try to block such an EIP (just silently grumble about it to myself).

author: sky.cactus
content: Historically, people have used the EIPs repository for politics, good ideas, bad ideas, best practices, thoughts, pontification, etc. and I would really like to see all of that go away so we can focus the repository on purely technical standards.

author: samwilsn
content: To be clear, it would still be a technical specification.

author: sky.cactus
content: The "what to include in pending pool" is more of a "best practice" or "good idea".

author: sky.cactus
content: Currently, clients implement *similar* strategies but there are subtle differences and there is absolutely no requirement that all clients follow the same rules.

author: samwilsn
content: I can see the logic there.

author: sky.cactus
content: So while you could define a technical specification, it wouldn't need to be a *standard* which is the other requirement for an EIP (IMO).

author: sky.cactus
content: It changes it from a "Standard" to a "Good Idea".

author: sky.cactus
content: Good ideas are incredibly valuable!  I just dislike them in the EIPs repository is all.

author: samwilsn
content: It'd be a "without this the feature opens an attack vector on the network" level of good idea.

author: sky.cactus
content: There are entire books just about Good Ideas (e.g., design pattern books, architecture books, etc.).  But you don't see any of that show up in RFCs.

author: sky.cactus
content:
> It'd be a "without this the feature opens an attack vector on the network" level of good idea.
<@!689161464829050960> Yeah, for that reason I *do* think it is worth mentioning in the security considerations.

author: sky.cactus
content: Anyone implementing this **SHOULD** be aware of the pitfalls and providing a workaround for them is a *very reasonable* thing to include in the security considerations section I think.

author: sky.cactus
content: Figuring out how much to include in that section is a bit of an art.

author: sky.cactus
content: You don't want to give people just the problem and no solutions, but at the same time you don't want to write a book in that section either.

author: sky.cactus
content: I think as a first step, just extracting all of the pending pool stuff from ## Specification and putting it in ## Security Considerations would be good.  From there we can take a look and see what opportunities we may have for cleaning it up/whittling it down a bit.

author: samwilsn
content: Not at all. The EIP currently lists one prefix (literally `if(msg.sender != shr(-1, 12)) { LOG1(msg.sender, msg.value); return }`). Further prefixes would just be discussed without an EIP then?

author: samwilsn
content: Thanks for the suggestion! I'll bring that up, and make a PR.

author: sky.cactus
content: Out of curiosity, why does that prefix help?

author: sky.cactus
content: Oh, is the idea that the contract cannot be called by anything?

author: samwilsn
content: It prevents calls into the AA contract from other contracts.

author: sky.cactus
content: I see.

author: sky.cactus
content: That feels like it makes contract wallets next to useless?

author: sky.cactus
content: They won't work with any ERC-223 tokens, for example.

author: sky.cactus
content: Nor will they work with any contract that issues a callback to the caller (like Uniswap does with its flash loans).

author: sky.cactus
content: You'll end up *less* capable than an EOA in terms of what you can do in some regards.

author: sky.cactus
content: (note: changing my hat from EIP editor to Ethereum user and smart wallet author now)

author: samwilsn
content: I appreciate all your hats!

author: sky.cactus
content: I have a smart wallet that I personally think *everyone* with large amounts of money should use (or use something with a similar feature set).  It currently won't work with AA due to the lack of access to `timestamp`, and the inability to call it from another contract castrates some of its usefulness, and it won't be able to do things like Uniswap flash loans, nor receive ERC-223 tokens.

author: sky.cactus
content: It *feels* like the current iteration of AA is just too limited to be of *real* value.

author: sky.cactus
content: It solves maybe a single niche case (multisig holding ETH), but not much else.

author: samwilsn
content: You could probably work around ERC-223 and flashloans with an intermediary contract.

author: sky.cactus
content: Oh, this isn't <#700028534114222171> maybe we should move there now?

author: samwilsn
content: heh, probably

author: sky.cactus
content: Should EIP discussion issues be closed when their EIP is final/withdrawn/abandoned/stagnant?  Example: https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/issues/2309

author: sky.cactus
content: Still need feedback from other editors on <https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/1297>.

author: sky.cactus
content:
<@!425279588009246720> What I learned today in the EIP-IP meeting is that the real debate we were all having (which I didn't understand previously) is whether or not there should be a negative status that has finality (cannot move backward on the flowchart).  I previously thought that you could always go back to draft from stagnant/withdrawn/abandoned, while it seems others believe that there should be a status for "dead and never coming back, this number is officially burned and will never become used".
I'm personally on the fence as to whether there is value in an unresurrectable status, but if I accept that there is then I think having a different status for unresurrectable and resurrectable is valuable.  I'm not sure if you were aware of that distinction previously or not, but wanted to share since you weren't at the meeting today.
